channel.title: Daily Feed (Updated 9 AM BD)
channel.description: Daily Feed (Updated 9 AM BD) generated by script

item.title: A reality check for BRICS and the lofty dedollarisation agenda
item.description: Local currency deals are growing, but a unified challenge to dollar hegemony remains a distant dream.

item.title: Terrorism returns to Delhi with a troubling new profile
item.description: A murky explosion in India last week dredges up old concerns.

item.title: Bangladesh’s War Crimes Court Sentences Sheikh Hasina to Death
item.description: The ousted leader was found guilty of ordering a deadly crackdown on last year’s student-led uprising.

item.title: The troubling reality of DeepSeek’s AI model
item.description: With genuine ideological and existential threats to consider, the next iteration of AI will be critical.

item.title: A huge corruption scandal threatens Ukraine’s government
item.description: Volodymyr Zelensky faces his biggest challenge since the invasion

item.title: Should U.S. Development Loans Go to Rich Countries?
item.description: The U.S. Development Finance Corporation was created to help alleviate global poverty. Trump has other ideas.

item.title: Don’t cheer the end of America’s obesity crisis just yet
item.description: The evidence so far is weak

item.title: An Unusual Election in Iraq Offers the U.S. an Unusual Opportunity
item.description: Baghdad is turning away from Tehran. Can Washington capitalize on it?

item.title: Russia’s militant bloggers are clashing with their own regime
item.description: Bashing the army for failing to crush Ukraine can land you in jail

item.title: The War Room newsletter: Ukraine’s war needs more than drones
item.description: Shashank Joshi, our defence editor, says survival on the front line is anything but simple

item.title: The Perils and Pitfalls of a U.S.-Saudi Defense Pact
item.description: U.S. troops would be obliged to defend Riyadh.

item.title: The Perils and Pitfalls of a U.S.-Saudi Defense Pact
item.description: U.S. troops would be obliged to defend Riyadh.

item.title: Europe sees China as a rival. China sees Europe as a has-been
item.description: Yet China may be underestimating Europe’s willingness to push back

item.title: Shut up, or suck up? How CEOs are dealing with Donald Trump
item.description: Chief executives are learning to live with a unique commander-in-chief

item.title: China’s Naval Strategy With 3 Aircraft Carriers
item.description: The Fujian marks a new phase for China’s naval aviation capability.

item.title: The Stablecoin Threat
item.description: Far too little attention has been paid to the fact that stablecoins could erode governments' control over money and debt, fundamentally reshaping how modern economies manage inflation, stabilize markets, and finance public spending. By catering to a politically connected industry, the United States is playing with fire.

item.title: What to Expect From Trump’s Meeting With MBS
item.description: The crown prince’s visit could result in a new U.S.-Saudi defense agreement.

item.title: The Deathonomics of Putin’s War
item.description: “Black widows” marrying soldiers to collect death benefits are symptomatic of society-wide rot.

item.title: Mongolia’s MPP Taps Uchral Nyam-Osor as Chair
item.description: Will the change mark a new chapter for the ruling party, or is the promise of reform a facade?

item.title: Building Bridges in a Divided World
item.description: Though it feels like the global order is fragmenting as more countries embrace zero-sum thinking and turn inward, this trend is far from universal. At a recent summit in Colombia, European, Latin American, and Caribbean leaders doubled down on their commitment to economic cooperation.

item.title: The 27th Amendment and Pakistan’s Emerging Military Posture
item.description: Don’t sleep on the 27th Amendment’s strategic reorientation of Pakistan’s defense architecture.

item.title: How Conscription Reshaped Myanmar’s Conflict
item.description: Forced recruitment has helped reverse momentum back in the military’s favor, even as it pushes many young men to flee.

item.title: As Saudi Crown Prince Visits Washington, What’s New Zealand’s Strategy for the Gulf?
item.description: For New Zealand, the six Gulf countries have also become increasingly essential – especially in trade, but also in wider strategic terms.

item.title: Good Neighbors: Australia, Indonesia Sign Security Treaty
item.description: The efforts the Australian government has made to build a cooperative and friendly relationship with Indonesia have been significant and important. But there’s more to be done.

item.title: Climate and Development Finance Must Be Integrated
item.description: Much of the international community has been under the illusion that climate action and development are different pursuits. But to make progress on both agendas, the delegates at this year’s United Nations Climate Change Conference must recognize that they are one and the same, and begin building an integrated financing system.

item.title: Global shipping carbon levy shelved for one year
item.description:
On October 17th the Environmental Policy Committee of the…

The post Global shipping carbon levy shelved for one year appeared first on Economist Intelligence Unit.

item.title: Try, Try Again: New Bills Submitted to Address the Jackson-Vanik Problem
item.description: Two new bills have been submitted to the U.S. Congress to deal with the Cold War-era Jackson-Vanik amendment.

item.title: In Central Asia, Calls to Bring Back the Death Penalty Are Growing Louder
item.description: With violence against women and girls escalating to its most brutal expression – sexual assaults and murders of minors – people in Kyrgyzstan and Uzbekistan are reconsidering the abolition of the death penalty.

item.title: PS Events: COP30 Studio Sessions Fireside
item.description: present a fireside chat from COP30 in Belém, Brazil.

item.title: Can Trump Bring Peace to Gaza?
item.description: With his 20-point peace plan for Gaza, US President Donald Trump is betting on economic integration and infrastructure connectivity to nurture long-term stability in the Middle East. While there are plenty of hurdles to overcome, Trump may have the necessary leverage, especially over Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu.

item.title: Bangladesh’s Ousted Prime Minister Sheikh Hasina Sentenced to Death
item.description: Hasina and her home minister have been found guilty of crimes against humanity during the mass uprising last year, resulting in the death of 1,400 people.

item.title: Can the American Right Find Its Way Back?
item.description: Under the influence of Donald Trump and his MAGA movement, the American right has become unrecognizable to those who remain committed to the values espoused by Ronald Reagan and Margaret Thatcher. The question now is whether the Republican Party can still recover their brand of dignified conservatism.

item.title: What Pakistan’s 2025 Army Reforms Really Mean for the Country
item.description: While army influence was previously exercised informally over its sister institutions, it has now been enshrined in law.

item.title: How Mamdani Taps Into an American Socialist Tradition
item.description: The movement’s founders echoed the words of Thomas Paine and Abraham Lincoln much more than Karl Marx.

item.title: How Mamdani Taps Into an American Socialist Tradition
item.description: The movement’s founders echoed the words of Thomas Paine and Abraham Lincoln much more than Karl Marx.

item.title: ‘Good Enough’ Drones Have Become Geopolitical Chips
item.description: In Sudan and elsewhere, regional powers have used the weapons for leverage.

item.title: ‘Good Enough’ Drones Have Become Geopolitical Chips
item.description: In Sudan and elsewhere, regional powers have used the weapons for leverage.

item.title: A Grand Bargain With Venezuela
item.description: American force won’t dislodge Maduro, but American diplomacy might.

item.title: How to Fix Free Trade
item.description: A global customs union could solve the problem of imbalances.

item.title: Hundreds of Thousands Rally Against Corruption in the Philippines
item.description: The simmering public anger over corruption linked to flood control projects threatens to engulf the administration of President Ferdinand Marcos Jr.

item.title: Can the US Help Prevent an Escalation in India-Pakistan Tensions?
item.description: If Washington can leverage the newfound momentum in its ties with Islamabad to prevent destabilizing behavior, it can play a productive role.

item.title: Nauru’s latest deportee deal with Australia repeats old mistakes
item.description: As a mono-economy shifts from phosphate to people, the pattern of boom and bust continues unchanged.

item.title: India’s Ruling Alliance Sweeps Major State Election Amidst Vote Fraud Allegations
item.description: The BJP-led NDA secured 202 of the 243 seats in the Bihar assembly. Opposition parties have pointed to collusion between the BJP and the national election panel.

item.title: The paradox of US military retrenchment in the Asia-Pacific
item.description: A partial retreat in the region could backfire, flaming tensions and emboldening China’s aggression.

item.title: Agency preservation drives the Indonesia–Australia security treaty
item.description: The echoes of history are evident – only this time, trust may not be as important as the context.

item.title: Thailand Says US Trade Talks Still on Track, Despite Suspension of Cambodia Peace Deal
item.description: The outcome exposes the limits of using economic pressure to bring about a resolution of the border dispute between the two nations.

item.title: For Israel a psychological reckoning is the price of bloody victory
item.description: Trauma, rebellion and emigration surge alongside military ascendency

item.title: Is left-wing terrorism returning?
item.description: Incidents are indeed up sharply, but lethality remains extremely low compared with right-wing and jihadist violence.

item.title: Beware the scorching gold rally
item.description: Only one explanation for the surge makes sense. It will not reassure investors

item.title: Can Donald Trump deploy the National Guard whenever he likes?
item.description: The Supreme Court seems likely to say no
